docs.snippet: SUSSMAN--Harrison (Harry) passed away on August 5th in Forest Hills, NY. Born in Brooklyn on March 21, 1924, Harry was a beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend. A lifelong fan of the New York baseball Giants from boyhood, Harry possessed ...
docs.lead_paragraph: SUSSMAN--Harrison (Harry) passed away on August 5th in Forest Hills, NY. Born in Brooklyn on March 21, 1924, Harry was a beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend. A lifelong fan of the New York baseball Giants from boyhood, Harry possessed a marvelous combination of intelligence, caring, great humor, and personal style. He graduated from Madison High School and Brown University and served in the U.S. Army in Europe during World War ll. After more than 30 years in the securities business, Harry retired in 1990 as a Vice President at Morgan Stanley Inc. In retirement, Harry was a dedicated volunteer and continuing education student. He was also passionate about world travel, historical biography, Mozart and fine Italian wine. He is survived by Seena, devoted wife of 62 years, children Claudia and Matthew, son-in-law Kenneth Roberts, and grandchildren Joanna Sussman Roberts and Benjamin Sussman Roberts. He will be greatly missed.

docs.snippet: KARELSEN--Frank E. III (born February 24, 1927 - died August 27, 2013) was a fourth generation New Yorker who graduated from The Ethical Culture and Fieldston School, Columbia University and Yale Law School. A retired senior partner of the law fir...
docs.lead_paragraph: KARELSEN--Frank E. III (born February 24, 1927 - died August 27, 2013) was a fourth generation New Yorker who graduated from The Ethical Culture and Fieldston School, Columbia University and Yale Law School. A retired senior partner of the law firm of Kurzman, Karelsen and Frank, he was a beloved and devoted husband of Ursula Steiner Karelsen-who died in 2007-father, grandfather, uncle, and friend. He adored the law, Sinatra, Ellington, Armstrong, Durante, "Singin' in the Rain", baseball, politics, the theater and chocolate milkshakes. He is survived by his son Franklin, his two daughters, Juliet and Eva, and his five grandchildren. Contributions in his memory should be made to the Ramapo Anchorage Camp for Children or the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, organizations to which he dedicated his energies and care.

headline.main: There Are No Sound Moral Arguments Against Performance-Enhancing Drugs

docs.snippet: FLAKS--Stephen R. During the 1970s, on the nightly news in New York City, an elderly African-American grandmother spoke through tears about her lack of money to pay her bills, such as rent, heating and other apartment fees. If she could not pay he...
docs.lead_paragraph: FLAKS--Stephen R. During the 1970s, on the nightly news in New York City, an elderly African-American grandmother spoke through tears about her lack of money to pay her bills, such as rent, heating and other apartment fees. If she could not pay her bills, then she would probably die on the streets with her personal effects because her distant family did not have enough money to help her. A couple of hours later a mysterious venture capitalist drove up to the grandmother's small apartment in Harlem and handed her a check. He did this anonymously. This anonymous charitable donor had the name of Steve Flaks. He was a venture capitalist, family man, arts patron, world traveler, philanthropist, and cinema producer. He carved out his own American Dream, while always holding on to his integrity. Stephen Robert Flaks, Venture Capitalist and Renaissance man, age 72, resident of Scottsdale, AZ, died peacefully on August 30th at the Mayo Clinic in Phoenix. Steve, one of three children, was born in New York City, on January 1, 1941. He grew up in the shadows of Yankee Stadium in the Bronx. But like his dad Jack before him, he was a New York Giants baseball team supporter when they still played at the Polo Grounds. Steve Flaks was an outstanding student, graduating with a B.A. from CCNY Baruch College in 1961. Harvard offered him a scholarship to its Business School, but Steve decided to work for Dreyfus Investments. He then began his ascent on Wall Street, even setting up his own successful brokerage firm. He later managed a successful private biotech hedge fund and fulfilled his film production aspirations, producing two films. While earning profits on his stock holdings, his favorite beneficiaries represented educational access, women's rights, animal rights and the environment. He especially supported arts organizations and fine arts in the Scottsdale region. His activities did not however end with philanthropy. Always fascinated by history and culture, Steve and his wife Beverly visited many of the world's continents. They toured on African safaris, trekked through China and India, and travelled by boat through the Amazon in Brazil. He was also a passionate New York Giants football fan, attending two of their recent Super Bowls. Most importantly, Steve Flaks was a dedicated family man. He was very happily married to his wife Beverly for 46 years. They birthed two sons, James and David, and they have two beloved dogs, Luni and Luna. Two sisters, Betty and Vicki, and daughter-in-law Jen, married to David, survive him. His family plans to continue his philanthropic work, carrying on his vision to help the less fortunate.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAKS, STEPHEN R

docs.snippet: At the Montauk Brewing Company, the idea was never to wow city fashionistas; the business was always about the home brews of its three locally grown founders....
docs.lead_paragraph: At the Montauk Brewing Company, the idea was never to wow city fashionistas; the business was always about the home brews of its three locally grown founders.
docs.abstract: Neighborhood Joint column on Montauk Brewing Company; home brewery and bar grew out of home brews of East Hampton natives Vaughan Cutillo, Joseph Sullivan and Eric Moss; founders began company in 2012 in woodworking shop belonging to Cutillo's father.

headline.seo: At Montauk Brewing Company, Brews Are Served Year-Round
